issues.text: Whether the U.P. Large Land Holdings Tax Act, 1957 is unconstitutional and void as being beyond the legislative competence of the U.P. Legislature under Entry 49, List II of the Seventh Schedule?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention which has been raised by Mr. Goyal before us is that the Act is unconstitutional and void inasmuch as it is beyond the legislative competence of the P. Legislatur , and this contention raises the question about the construction of Entry 49 in List II of the 7th Schedule of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the multiple prescribed by the State Government under section 5(1) of the Act is invalid for failure to prescribe different multiples for different districts or classes of land?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Goyal then contends that the multiple prescribed by the State Government is invalid because it has been prescribed in a manner contrary to the mandatory requirement of a. 5(1).

issues.text: Whether section 5(1) of the Act contravenes Articles 14 and 19(1)(f) of the Constitution by conferring unfettered discretion on the State Government?
Whether the charging provisions of the Act contravene Articles 14, 19(1)(f) and 31 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: the said Act violates the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 14, 19 and 31 and as such, is void.

issues.text: Whether the rates fixed by the Schedule to the Act contravene Articles 14 and 19(1)(f)?
Whether the rates fixed by the State Government under section 5(1) are invalid for non-compliance with the provisions of that section?

arguments.court_reasoning: Words in Constitution must receive liberal construction; 'lands' includes agricultural lands; Entry 46 on agri income distinct; pith and substance is tax on land holdings.

arguments.claim: No violation of Art.14: reasonable classification (graded rates, >30 acres); Art.19(1)(f): procedure/machinery provided (Ch III).

anchor.surface_text: It is also true that the legislature is competent to classify persons or Properties into different categories and tax them differently, and if the classification thus made is rational

holdings.text: The U.P. Large Land Holdings Tax Act, 1957 is within the legislative competence of the U.P. Legislature under Entry 49, List II of the Seventh Schedule as 'lands' includes agricultural lands.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal construction of constitutional entries; pith and substance is tax on land holdings; Entry 46 on agri income does not exclude agri lands from Entry 49.

holdings.text: The notification prescribing multiples under section 5(1) complies with the statutory requirements and is valid.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the notification issued by the State Government on the 23rd April, 1958, shows that it has complied with the provisions of s. 5 (1). Under this notification, the multiple of 12-1/2 has been fixed for determining the annual value throughout U. P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'May' confers discretion, not obligation; different multiples prescribed for groves, regions, new lands.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) does not confer unfettered discretion and does not contravene Articles 14 or 19(1)(f).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion guided by local conditions and classes of land; practicable for legislature to delegate; notification shows rational classification.

holdings.text: The charging provisions of the Act do not contravene Articles 14, 19(1)(f) or 31.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasonable classification in rates and exemption; machinery/procedure in Ch III; Art.31(1) satisfied by valid law, Art.31(2) inapplicable to taxes.

holdings.text: The rates fixed by the Schedule do not contravene Articles 14 or 19(1)(f).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Graded rates based on annual value (rent); rational for differently valued holdings; legislative choice.

holdings.text: The rates under section 5(1) are valid and comply with the section.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the notification issued by the State Government on the 23rd April, 1958, shows that it has complied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification fixed different multiples for classes/districts as permitted.

holdings.text: The Act is not confiscatory in character nor a colourable piece of legislation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Figures show tax ~23% of net income, not confiscatory; no fraud or discrimination shown unlike Moopil Nair.

holdings.text: Validity of taxing statutes can be challenged under Part III if they violate fundamental rights, besides lack of competence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents like Yasin, United Motors, Bengal Immunity; distinguishes earlier views.

holdings.text: Article 31(2) is inapplicable to taxing statutes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxes not acquisition; Art.31(2A), 31(5)(b)(i) exclude taxes; Art.31(1) requires valid law.

holdings.text: Petitions Nos. 325 and 326 of 1960 are barred by res judicata.

outcome.relief_summary: All challenges to validity of U.P. Large Land Holdings Tax Act rejected on grounds of legislative competence, Arts. 14, 19(1)(f), 31, confiscatory nature, and colourable legislation; no relief to petitioner
